metadata.case_number: Criminal Appeal No. ... of 2008 (Special Leave Petition (Criminal) No. 5265 of 2007)

facts.text: Sanjay Pal got financed a Maruti Van bearing No. DL-1CB-4065 from Shri Manoj Kumar Sharma - Vijay Lakshmi Finance Investment Company for Rs. 30,000/- and paid Rs. 3954/- as first installment.
Man Mohan Sharma informed Sanjay Pal that the finance was fabricated, took the old R.C., gave new R.C. for Real Auto Deals run by his brother-in-law, and received the first payment and file.
Man Mohan Sharma received installments in cash every month without proper receipts on letterhead or stamp of Real Auto Deals; cheques encashed in different names instead of Real Auto Deals account.
Sanjay Pal stopped cheque payments upon noticing fraud and issued notice to pay in name of Real Auto Deals.
On 27.12.1995, Man Mohan Sharma with unknown person took the Maruti Van without consent using a paper stamped by police.
Vijay Lakshmi Finance, Real Auto Deals and Man Mohan Sharma sold the vehicle using forged signatures and fraud.
FIR No.50/1997 dated 31.01.1997 registered at P.S. Vivek Vihar, East Delhi under Sections 420/468/471/34/120-B IPC.
Charges framed against appellant Manoj Sharma and co-accused Man Mohan Sharma based on FIR.
Parties entered into amicable settlement; complainant filed affidavit withdrawing allegations against petitioners and FIR; agreed to pay Rs.45,000/- each to Manoj Sharma and Man Mohan Sharma.
Appellant filed writ petition in Delhi High Court to quash FIR on ground of settlement; rejected by High Court on 17.08.2007.
Special Leave Petition filed in Supreme Court, leave granted.

legal_issues.text: Whether a First Information Report under Sections 420/468/471/34/120-B IPC can be quashed under Section 482 CrPC or Article 226 of the Constitution when the accused and complainant have compromised and settled the matter.

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court has power under Section 482 CrPC or Article 226 to quash FIR/complaint/criminal proceedings even for non-compoundable offences where parties have settled, relying on B.S. Joshi v. State of Haryana.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: B.S. Joshi v. State of Haryana (2003) 4 SCC 675; Pepsi Foods Ltd. v. Special Judicial Magistrate (1998) 5 SCC 749

respondent_arguments.text: Decision in B.S. Joshi requires reconsideration as it departs from earlier views; offences under Sections 468, 471, 34, 120-B IPC are non-compoundable even with court permission per Section 320(9) CrPC; cannot quash indirectly what cannot be compounded directly.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Inspector of Police, CBI v. Rajagopal (2002) 9 SCC 533; K.G. Prem Shankar v. Inspector of Police JT 2002(7) SC 30; Textile Labour Association v. Official Liquidator JT 2004 Suppl.1 SC 1; Section 320 CrPC

court_reasoning.text: Power under Section 482 CrPC or Article 226 not circumscribed by Section 320 CrPC; depends on facts to prevent abuse of process or secure ends of justice; B.S. Joshi correctly states law that High Court can quash non-compoundable proceedings on settlement.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Dispute is of private nature; complainant not pursuing; continuing proceedings futile.

court_reasoning.text: High Court erred in refusing to quash under Article 226; should have taken pragmatic view given settlement and personal nature of dispute.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Exercise of power discretionary based on facts of each case.

court_reasoning.text: Section 482 has non-obstante clause overriding Section 320 in rare cases to secure ends of justice; B.S. Joshi followed, creating solution for hardships in non-compoundable cases like 498A; guidelines needed for future but quash here.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Not all non-compoundable offences quashable (e.g., 302 IPC); line to be drawn in future by larger Bench for civil-like disputes.

holdings.text: High Court has inherent power under Section 482 CrPC / Article 226 to quash FIR/criminal proceedings even for non-compoundable offences if settlement prevents abuse of process/secures ends of justice.
In facts of case, criminal proceedings quashed as futile post-settlement.

precedents_cited.case_name: B.S. Joshi v. State of Haryana
precedents_cited.relevance: Power under S.482 CrPC to quash non-compoundable proceedings on settlement upheld.

precedents_cited.case_name: Pepsi Foods Ltd. v. Special Judicial Magistrate
precedents_cited.relevance: No rigid formula for exercising S.482; depends on facts to prevent abuse/secure justice.

precedents_cited.case_name: Inspector of Police, CBI v. Rajagopal
precedents_cited.relevance: Cited by respondent against quashing non-compoundable offences.

precedents_cited.case_name: K.G. Prem Shankar v. Inspector of Police
precedents_cited.relevance: Cited by respondent against B.S. Joshi.

precedents_cited.case_name: Textile Labour Association v. Official Liquidator
precedents_cited.relevance: Cited by respondent against B.S. Joshi.
Followed B.S. Joshi in quashing proceedings post-compromise.

precedents_cited.case_name: Madhu Limaye v. State of Maharashtra
precedents_cited.relevance: S.482 not exercisable against express bar, but exception for justice.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Karnataka v. L. Muniswamy
precedents_cited.relevance: Quash if no chance of conviction/ends of justice.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code, 1860
statutes_cited.relevance: Offences in FIR; 420 compoundable with permission, others non-compoundable.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973
statutes_cited.relevance: S.482 inherent power to quash overrides S.320 non-compoundability in rare cases; S.320 lists compoundable offences.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: High Court's writ jurisdiction to quash FIR/proceedings on settlement.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court order set aside; FIR No.50/1997 dated 31.01.1997 and criminal proceedings before Additional Chief Metropolitan Magistrate, Karkardooma Courts, Delhi quashed.
outcome.relief_granted: Quashing of FIR and criminal proceedings

key_quotes.text: Exercise of such power would depend upon the facts and circumstances of each case but with the sole object of preventing abuse of the process of any Court, or otherwise to secure the ends of justice.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines scope of S.482 CrPC from Pepsi Foods, applied here.

key_quotes.text: In the facts of this case we are of the view that continuing with the criminal proceedings would be an exercise in futility.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The words 'Nothing in this Code' used in Section 482 is a non obstante clause, and gives it overriding effect over other provisions in the Cr.P.C.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains why S.482 prevails over S.320.
